citations.narrative:
None of the adult dogs in the kennel are properly identified by a tag, tattoo, or microchip. Improper identification on all
adult dogs doesn't ensure the dogs can be easily identified and traced by an APHIS official. All adult dogs must be
identified by tag, tattoo, or microchip. Correct by 8/26/23.

A black and white female rat terrier (#1009) escaped from the licensee's premises on 4/12/23. The licensee was unable to
find the dog. A dog that is able to escape from the licensee's premises could get injured by a car, could become prey to a
wild animal, may not be able to find proper food, water, or shelter, and could end up deceased. The licensee must
properly contain all regulated dogs so the dogs are unable to escape from the licensee's premises.

The top row of the outdoor kennels doesn't have a proper drainage system set up. Plastic sheeting is set up to direct the
urine and fecal material towards the building and from there the licensee can spray the waste material towards one end.
There is a gap between where the building meets the plastic sheeting allowing the waste material to drain into the
enclosures below. By allowing the waste material to drain into the enclosures below, the dogs below are potentially being
exposed to various diseases and parasites. The drainage system for the upper row of enclosures needs to be fixed so it
doesn't allow waste material to drain into the enclosures below. Correct by 8/2/23.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The licensee has a pellet stove in his kennel. Behind the pellet stove on the floor is a black waste material (licensee
referred to as creosote) that is building up. In addition, small bugs were observed to be crawling around on a penicillin
bottle which was next to the vaccines in the cold storage container. Waste material from the pellet stove may be
hazardous to the dogs and anyone working in the kennel. Bugs crawling around in cold storage could contaminate any
vaccines or medications being stored in there. Waste material on the floor in the kennel needs to be cleaned up on a
regular basis to prevent build-up. The cold storage needs to be cleaned out on a regular basis to remove any bugs that
are present. In addition, the licensee should look at ways of preventing bugs from entering the cold storage.

One adult and two puppies had feces caked in their fur around the anus. Caked up feces could block the anus and the
dog could have trouble defecating if it were to get any worse. In addition caked up feces can cause irritation and infection
of the skin. The licensee must groom the dogs on a regular basis to prevent feces from building up around the anus.
Correct by 7/28/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
End of report.
Additional Inspectors:
Jennifer Walker, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
None of the adult dogs in the kennel are properly identified by a tag, tattoo, or microchip. Improper identification on all 
adult dogs doesn't ensure the dogs can be easily identified and traced by an APHIS official. All adult dogs must be 
identified by tag, tattoo, or microchip. Correct by 8/26/23. 
3.1(a)  Critical Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
A black and white female rat terrier (#1009) escaped from the licensee's premises on 4/12/23. The licensee was unable to 
find the dog. A dog that is able to escape from the licensee's premises could get injured by a car, could become prey to a 
wild animal, may not be able to find proper food, water, or shelter, and could end up deceased. The licensee must 
properly contain all regulated dogs so the dogs are unable to escape from the licensee's premises. 
3.1(f) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
The top row of the outdoor kennels doesn't have a proper drainage system set up. Plastic sheeting is set up to direct the 
urine and fecal material towards the building and from there the licensee can spray the waste material towards one end. 
There is a gap between where the building meets the plastic sheeting allowing the waste material to drain into the 
enclosures below. By allowing the waste material to drain into the enclosures below, the dogs below are potentially being 
exposed to various diseases and parasites. The drainage system for the upper row of enclosures needs to be fixed so it 
doesn't allow waste material to drain into the enclosures below. Correct by 8/2/23. 
3.11(c)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The licensee has a pellet stove in his kennel. Behind the pellet stove on the floor is a black waste material (licensee 
referred to as creosote) that is building up. In addition, small bugs were observed to be crawling around on a penicillin 
bottle which was next to the vaccines in the cold storage container. Waste material from the pellet stove may be 
hazardous to the dogs and anyone working in the kennel. Bugs crawling around in cold storage could contaminate any 
vaccines or medications being stored in there. Waste material on the floor in the kennel needs to be cleaned up on a

regular basis to prevent build-up. The cold storage needs to be cleaned out on a regular basis to remove any bugs that 
are present. In addition, the licensee should look at ways of preventing bugs from entering the cold storage. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
One adult and two puppies had feces caked in their fur around the anus. Caked up feces could block the anus and the 
dog could have trouble defecating if it were to get any worse. In addition caked up feces can cause irritation and infection 
of the skin. The licensee must groom the dogs on a regular basis to prevent feces from building up around the anus. 
Correct by 7/28/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.  
 
End of report. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Jennifer Walker, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
